article_text: Immigrant - help body advocated By BRUCE JUDDERY Canberra needs a centra! co-ordinating and "enabling" body to look after the interests of. immigrants, accord ing to a discussion paper prepared ior the ACT Council of Social Service. The paper, 'Immigrant Problems and Meeds in the ACT', also urges that the provision of inter preting and translation services in the Territory be rationalised through a consultative committee representing interested departments and other bodies, including ethnic groups. The committee would set standards of qualifications and recom mend courses of training, systems of employment and use. "Perhaps an ACT Migrant Resource Centre would be the appropriate employer of a panel of interpreters and trans lators to service the ACT", suggests Mr Peter Watnev, the paper's author. "Sixteen years of talk and reports should have provided sufficient material to achieve action this year. Interpreter service "The resource centre could perhaps establish a telephone interpreter ser vice and co-operate with such other telephone ser vices as Life Line pnd the Citizens Advice Bureau".  Mr Watriey's pape», drawing on 1971 census figures, says that 21.4 per cent of Canberra's popu lation was born in Europe (including 9.9 per cent from Britain and Ire land), and another 4.2 per cent from other countries. Queanbeyan's Europe bom population amounted to 25.9 per cent, only 5 per cent of which, came from Britain and Ireland. Problems faced by the migrant section oC the community included "the high cost of accom modation and the pur chase of essential capital equipment,' such as furn iture, refrigerator, wash ing machine and trans port", which put many migrant families in a "severe déficit position" on arrival here. Families under strain "This deficit aggra vates many of the newly arrived immigrants' pro blems", the paper states.' "For example, a family under strain through differing rates of assimi lating the new language suffer, the additional strain of both parents having to work outside the home to pay for their' capital pur chases, and having less time to devote to the business of the home and supporting the children. This effect has been com mented on by a number of welfare agencies in Canberra". Many immigrants had the strong feeling that, far from being welcome, "they are here on suffer ance .until they become as indistinguishable as possible from Australians in language, speech, food, clothes and culture". For many, learning a language was difficult. The Canberra Technical College had commented on the numbers of poten tially good tradesmen who were deficient in English — often they could speak, but not read or write it — or even illiterate. Many did not. wish to admit their illit eracy, and required personal tutoring in the language. The paper continues, "It is not surprising thai young children, exposed to English, having to learn it at school and rc ceiving 'competent instruction, learn English faster than do their parents. A parent going out to work . .. learn faster than a parent working with fellow countrymen or staying at home ... 'Teachers can help' "The end result is alien ation and tension in the family and a tendency for the children, under press ure from their teachers and their peers, to reject their mother tongue and culture. The results of this process are well known to welfare, workers in Can berra and are a cost to the community in both finan cial and cultural terms". There was no public interpreter service in the ACT, Mr Walney point ed out Though courts paid the cost of inter preters those on, for in stance, the Canberra Hospital's list of inter preters ' were not paid extra for this service. The paper suggests thai teachers can "help to re lease the immigrant chil dren from pressure to re ject .their mother .tongue and cultures by positively promoting interest in these and by a scrupulous avoidance of Austra lianising names and by treating foreign names, however unusual or diffi cult, with genuine re spect". The ACT Schools Authority, - the Com monwealth . Teachers Federation, the Com monwealth Teaching Ser vice and ethnic groups should determine ways to start a pilot scheme to teach irii migrant lan guages and cultures in both primary and second ary schools. using migrant resources, if nec essary by relaxing quali fications.

article_text: BRITAIN Immigrant ban alleged LONDON, Thursday (AAP-Reuter). — An immigrant advisory group yesterday accused Britain of throwing all pretensions of decency and humanity to the winds in order to prevent a group of its own citi- zens from gaining entry here. In a survey called Re- port on Shuttlecocks, the joint council for the wel- fare of immigrants quoted the case of an east Afri- can who spent 60 hours flying after being refused entry to Britain. The man had been flown from London to Sydney via Burundi, Ruanda, South Africa and Mauritius and back again to London where he was put in a detention centre. "By that time he was completely disorientated and did not know what the date or day of the week was. "The British Govern- ment over a period of three months threw all pretensions of decency and humanity to the winds in order to prevent a group of its own subjects from entering the country of which they were citizens", the report said. In Strasbourg, France, the European Commission of Human Rights opened yesterday a hearing here of cases brought against the British Government by 31 Kenya and Uganda Asians.

article_text: Russian immigrant teaches Hittite “THE STUDY of the Hittite language is free of ideology, and: this is one of its at tractions,’’ explains Galya Kellerman, philologist, in structor and Ph.D. student in the small but active Depart ment of Assyriology at the Hebrew University of Jerusalem. Ms Kellerman, a new immigrant from Russia, states that she was always inclined towards the humanities, but that in the USSR all its other fields were deeply affected by communist ideology. She now teaches Hittite and is also currently writing her Doctoral disser tation, to aid in which she was recen tly awarded a scholarship from the Mauricio Richter Fund, which will assure her continued research and teaching for the next academic year. Galya Kellerman immigrated to Israel in November 1973, immediately following the Yom Kippur War, having graduated from Moscow State University, summa cum laude, in Classics and Hittite, an ancient Indo European language written in cuneiform. It was spoken by the people who inhabited ancient Anatolia, in the area that is Turkey, from ap proximately 1700 to 1200 BCE, and was only deciphered as recently as World War 1. Ms Kellerman worked one year at the Institute of Oriental Studies of the Academy of Sciences in Moscow, but resigned her position there before ap plying to immigrate in order to avoid making problems for those who had earlier helped her professionally. During the six months before she left Russia, she studied Hebrew in an underground ulpan which enabled her to teach in Hebrew after only a few months of further ulpan studies in Israel. WHILE HER emphasis had been linguistic, she adapted herself quickly to the Department of Assyriology in Israel, where the stress is on civilisations and cultures in ancient Western Asia. . She acquired a basic knowledge of the other major cuneiform languages (of Babylon and Assyria) and is now able to use Hittite as a tool in un derstanding Hittite culture, and as ar inseparable entity of cuneiforir literature. Prof. Hayim Tadmor, head of th&lt department, describes her as i brilliant philologist “unique in hei devotion to scholarship and an out standing asset to the department ii her exciting new field.” She is among the very few Hittit&lt scholars in the world, and the only on&lt at the Hebrew University, who work: from graphic reproductions or tran sliterations of cuneiform tablets. article_text: American denied immigrant status BEN-GURION AIRPORT: A family of five would-be immig rants from Los Angeles who had been detained in the absorption terminal because the father has a history of mental illness were granted three-month (tourist) visas. Members of the Habad Hasidic movement, to which the family of Abraham Bar-On (MacKeagan until his con version six months ago) belongs, said they would take the family to Kfar Habad immediately. Bar-On, the Jewish divorcee he married after his conversion, and her three young children by her first husband — had originally planned to settle in the Kiryat Habad section of Safad. The family, which had made arrangements for aliya through the aliya of fices in Los Angeles, was detained on its entrance when it developed that there was an Interior Ministry order barring MacKeagan’s return to the country. This was because on a previous visit he had been hospitalized for a time in a Jerusalem mental in stitution. Under the Law of Return, a history of mental illness is sufficient grounds for refusing a person im migrant status. The family were to have been sent back to the US, but Habad lawyers in tervened and Attorney General Aharon Barak or dered a 24-hour stay. The Interior Ministry tourist visas then followed. Habad lawyers said that they will continue their ef forts to get the Bar-Ons temporary resident status. According to the Interior Ministry spokesman, Bar On — then MacKeagan — visited Israel six or seven times between 1963 and 1972. Itim reports that on his last visit, with his first, Christian wife, he was hospitalized. On his release they retur ned, divorced, and he joined the Habad movement and converted. His Jewish wife, whose children are aged 7,5 and 3, is also a recent addition to the Habad movement. Before it took the step of issuing visas, the Interior Ministry had said it wanted to clear up two matters: whether MacKeagan had been properly converted, and whether the couple had the right to take the children out of the US.

article_text: Leader at Immigrant Conference Victorian Jewish communal leader, Mr Walter Lippanann, attended the recent 65th meet ing of the Immigrant Advisory Council in Canberra. Mr Lippmann, who is presi dent of the. Victorian Jewish Board of Deputies, was among twenty-one members of the Council at the meeting. The studies will be carried out by three committees of the Council. The Committee on Social Patterns will be investigating and reporting on the departure of settlers from Australia. They would inquire into the role of national groups. The Commit tee on Citizenship would con sider a wide range of factors concerned with naturalisation of eligible migrants. The Com mittee on Migrant Education will examine and report on varous aspects of the teaching of English to migrants. Chairman of the Council is Senator Gordon Davidson, of South Australia. He has been particularly in terested in the demography of' Australian Jewry and has pub: lished several works on this subject.

article_text: Soviet immigrant demand voice TEL AVIV: Soviet immigrants claim that they are denied representation in the various organ* isations purporting to work on behalf of Soviet Jews. The charge was made by the head of the Soviet Im migrants’ Association, Grisha Feigin, in a strongly worded message to par ticipants in the Jewish Agency Assembly. Feigin said that this was true both of the Jewish Agency and other organizations. Instead of giving new-comers a say in the struggle against Soviet Aliya restrictions and the tendency of Soviet Jews to ‘drop-out’ in Vienna, these vital decisions “are left in the hands of ‘veteran Zionist Functionaries,’ for most of whom the issue of Soviet Jewry is at best a hobby and at worst a business.” “At a time when everyone deals with Soviet Jews — from Jerusalem to i Washington, via Paris and London — the Soviet im migrants themselves are not given a chance to con tribute to this struggle. Meanwhile, over 110,000 immigrants from the USSR reside in Israel and can be of incalculable help,” Feigin’s message con tinued. Feigin further accused the Jewish establishment and World Jewry of “taking up the cause of Soviet Jews only when the Jewish re-awakening in the USSR had gained such in tensity that it broke through the Iron Curtain. We fought before that too — but the world was silent.” The activist chairman of the Immigrant Association finally asked the Jewish Agency not to regard the whole issue of Soviet Jewry “as political merchandise to be bartered between the Great Powers and used by them as a bargaining card.”

article_text: Immigrant checks too lax: Cilento MELBOURNE, Sunday. - Immigrants should be examined for disease and weak blood in the same way as cattle imported into Australia, Sir Raphael Cilento said today. Sir Raphael, a Queens- land tropical - medicine specialist, was addressing a seminar of the Australian League of Rights, "We must be constantly vigilant, constantly exam- ining the purity of our racial blood to prevent racial clots which might end in disaster", he said. "The tensions and dis- satisfactions of minorities can become these clots". Mr Robert Clarke, of the Immigration Control Association, said the Gov- ernment was undermining the Australian heritage by bringing in more and more people who could not be satisfactorily assimilated. "The unassimilable groups in this country are a sore which will even tually become an ulcer", he forecast. The right-wing league came to public notice in August when the Country Party leader and deputy Prime Minister, Mr An- thony, attacked it for try ing to use the Country Party to "push its own views". He said the League had tended to be anti-semitic, pro-Nazi and racialist in its views. Other guest speakers to day were to have been the Victorian Attorney-Gen- eral, Mr Reid, and a nu- trition expert. Sir Stanton Micks. The national director of the League. Mr Eric But- ler, said Mr Reid had de- cided not to speak for "political reasons", and Sir Stanton Hicks had been called "elsewhere".

article_text: RHODESIA Immigrant ban makes trouble SALISBURY, Wed nesday (AAP-Reutcr). - A Rhodesian Gov ernment ban on non white immigration has provoked angry protests among the country's coloured and Asian people and threatened more racial discord at a critical time in Rho desia's history. A new whites-only im migration policy, which has led to the refusal of work permits to highly skilled non-whites and the expulsion of partners in mixed marriages, has emerged at a time when London and Salisbury are about to open a new phase in negotiations to settle the six-year-old Rhodesian in dependence deadlock. Political sources feel that though the new colour dis pute would not necessarily damage chances of an Anglo - Rhodesian settle ment, it would certainly not improve the atmo sphere. The Government clamp down on non-white immi gration came to light when the National Association of Coloured People, repre senting Rhodesia's 16,500 people of mixed race, sent a delegation to the Minis ter for Immigration, Mr Peter Van Der Byl, to ask why work permits were refused to four highly qualified coloureds whose skills could scarcely be spared in Rhodesia. The four were a doctor, a nurse, a dicsel mechanic and a teacher. The doctor, a South African, had accepted a post as assistant medical officer of health in Salis bury. The Salisbury City Coun cil knew he was coloured and considered him well-' suited for the post. Previously the Govern ment had allowed a small number of Asians and col oureds into the country on temporary permits, but the NACP delegation was told by Mr Van Der Byl that the ban was now total. "We're shocked, but at least we know where we stand", said NACP secre tary. Mr Eugene Robinson. "We have been trying for years to find out just what the Government's official policy is about the coloured population".

IRAG Immigrant Action Group Formed. A group of students from the IJNSW Campus have established a body called the Immigration Research and Action Group (f.R.A.G.). s The idea for the group arose firstly Out of the frustration experienced by almost everyone who has tried to study migrant piobiems and then do something about them. -This is bscause:- 'i: '' 1. The migrant studies, research aid services are notoriously un co-ordinated V you have to go all over Sydney, Melbourne and Canberra to get information, . 2. Workers in the field (including researchers) are isolated from each other wheir it comes to knowing what is going or and who's doing what. Word of mouth turns out to be the only means of communication available. Secondly, the idea also came about because of the deteriorating economic situation in Post-Industrial Australia and the effects this is having and will have on migrants. How will Technological Change md restructuring affect migrants now and iii the future ? s thirdly it is not clear what the Government Y or anvone else for that matter) intends to do about the situation as outlined above. The only thing is a definite increase in migrant intake and the allocation of a miniscule $ 50 million for migrant services and programmes (that's to be divided among all states all programmes and services !) This sum wouldn't be enough to pay the unemployment benefits for three weeks. Fourthly, Sydney lags in terms of research and information behind say, Melbourne, where there is a Migrant Studies Centre at Monash University which puts out the quarterly, "Ethnic Studies". Melbourne also has the Clearing House on Migration Issues not to mention the Brotherhood of St. Lawrence all of whom conduct research and distribute information about migrants. _ Finally the information available on migrants (such as statistics etc.) is both inadequate and hard to get. The quality of the research is often poor and bad research is often worse than no research at all. And so I.R.A.G. was established not to solve all these problems but to at least fill in some of the gaps. The aims of the group are necessarily limited. The immediate aims are:— 1. extend the membership of the :gt©up 4 Law, Medcine, Social Work etc. students who are interested in migrants and their" problems are needed, they will have an important role to play in the group 2. Get a resources cerise going immediately. The centre will offer assistance, guidance and information to any student or member of staff studying a migrant problem or issues. The resources centre will hold certain publications such as Government and other reports, statistics, Press releases by the Government, journals etc. as much as the group can afford. It will also have people who've done the detective work while researching a subject. The centre would also hope to publish a basic resources list. 3. Co-ordinate, and link all those people on this campus who are doing work in the area of migrants. The group proposes to do this through a newsletter of some kind as well as regular seminars, film nights etc. 4. Members of the group, on an individual basis or with the group as a whole, may be able to help individual migrants, or migrant community leaders with a problem, submissions, etc. by offering their research capabilities, their time or their 2nd language ability. 5. Improving communications between australians and migrants by presenting the fact, such as in the Social Security fraud episode and now in the Drug Inquiry allegations. It should be emphasised that the view concerning member's participation and contribution tends to be: from each member according to his/her capabilities and to the amount of time he/she has available. NZ MAY STEM IMMIGRANT FLOW Hew Zealand's Overseas Trade Minister, Joseph Walding, said his Government was involved in a comprehensive review of its immigration policy which "implies the possibility that restraints of some kind will have to be imposed/' AAP reports from London. The M i ni s t e r's statement, at a London Chamber of Commerce meeting, was seen as a modification of remarks he made to ne,wsmen on Monday that restrictions in the number of British and other im rn.i g r a n t s would be announced within the next few weeks. In- Wellington the New Zealand Immigration Minister Fraser Colman quickly denied that such a decision had already been taken. Mr Walding, whose clamp-down statement was widely reported in the British press, told the Chamber of Commerce that whatever the details-of his Government's policy he had no doubt that the bulk of New Zealand's im- migrants' would continue to come from Britain. Any new measures should not be taken as a sign of diminishing friendship between the two countries, he said.

article_text: Immigrant pest threatens nation's lucerne The spotted alfalfa aphid, one of the world's most destructive and mobile pests, is cutting a swathe of destruction across Australia. It was first noticed in Australia only a few months ago and has already ravaged large areas of luccrnc in eastern Australia. If its spread is not checked it is expccted that damage to lucerne grown for hay and grazing could total $50 million. Senator Lajovic (Lib, NSW) asked in the Senate on Tuesday what action the CSIRO was taking to stop the insect. The Minister for Science, Senator Webster, said, "The CSIRO has brought in from the US three parasitic wasp species which have been used successfully there to keep down the population of the spotted aphid". Senator Webster said the CSIRO had been interested in developing lucerne strains that could be resistant to the aphid before it was known to be in Australia, and was working with State departments of agriculture and some Commonwealth departments to develop a plan of action.

article_text: IMMIGRANT INCREASE FROM SOVIET UNION JERUSALEM: Overall immigration in the first half of 1972 is up significantly over the same period last year. But immigration from non-Communist countries is down by 10 per cent. these points were made last week by Mr Arye Pincus, chairman off the Jewish Agen cy Executive, at a press con ference in Jerusalem. Mr Pincus said that 28,000 immigrants have arrived this year compared to 18,000 in the first half of 1971. He ex pressed confidence that the forecast of 60-65,000 immi grants for the year would hold true. Immigration from the USSR Was maintaining its pace, Mr Pincus said, and there was no reason to believe the flow would be impeded. He expressed concern, how ever, about a decline from Western countries. A 10 per cent drop has been recorded from the US and a 5-6 per cent decline from France. immigration from South America, on the other hand, has increased 6-7 per cent. Mr Pincus, who has just re turned rom a trip abroad, said that prospective immigrants were puit off by what they be- 1 lieved to be an atmosphere 1 hostile to immigrants and by the difficulties in obtaining reasonably priced housing. He said the make-up of the current crop of Soviet immi grants was “more healthy” than in the past. Immigrants were now coming from all j parts of the Soviet Union, he said. ] Mr Pincus predicted that j fund-raising drives abroad will do even better this year than in 1971, when a record $420m was raised. They encounter the novel opportunity of being able to do as they wish as unfettered human beings. They need no longer cringe as barely tolerated inferiors of second- or third-class citizenship who are denied the rights and privileges enjoyed by normal members of society, because' they are of a different faith or “ peoplehood ” than the majority How does this- newly found sensation of expansiveness ex press itself in terms of actual individual experience? Here are several instances describing the first contacts with life in Israel by recent immi grants originating in Eastern 'Europe, North Africa and Asia. It is by no means a complete picture but a random collection that illustrates Benjamin Frank lin’s aphorism, “Where liberty dwells, there, is my country.” To begin with, integration into an untrammelled environment initially produces a species of bewilderment among newcomers which reflects the trauma of their previous existence. The young man and his wife, both in their mid-20s, had arrived some time ago from a country in Eastern Europe. article_text: NEW IMMIGRANT I AND ISRAEL LAW By MICHAEL SHINE The description of Israel as a 6 4country of immigration par excellence” is reflected no less in its legal system than in any other area of its social structure. For, by a peculiar inver sion, the status of those Jews, for the purposes of determin ing Israel nationality and citizenship, already in the country, is derived from and acquired by the same formula as that applied to immi grants, and not vice versa, as might reasonably have been anticipated. This idea is the product of “Shevut" — “Return", an ideological concept which has been employed by the Knesset as a legal fiction. Law of Return The primary enactment governing the right to come to Israel, and providing for the status of Jews immigrat ing there, is the Law of Re turn, passed by the Knesset in 1950. This Act re-affirms the fundamental principal that eve.ry Jew has the right to come to this country as an “oleh”. Recent amending legisla tion has extended the defini tion of Jew, for the purpose of this Law, to include a person bom of a Jewish mother, or a non-Jew who be came a Jew by conversion and is not a member of another faith. The same amendment pro vides that the rights of a Jewish immigrant, pursuant to the Law of Return, as well as pursuant to any other statute, shall accrue to the children, grandchildren and spouse of a Jew, as well as the spouse of such child or grandchild, irrespective of whether such Jew is living in or emigrated to Israel him self. A person entering in Israel as an “oleh”, within the meaning of the Law of Re turn, automatically acquires Israeli citizenship. ne s However, a Jew settling in Israel need not become an “oleh” immediately but may take out a temporary resi dence visa, which is normally renewable for a period not exceeding three years. There are several categories of temporary residence, the type to be acquired by intend ing immigrants being classi fied as “A-l", a status en titling its holders to enjoy substantially all the rights of a new immigrant. Thereafter, if he intends to reside permanently in the country, he is faced with two alternatives: he may either become an “oleh” and take out Israeli citizenship, or if he does not wish to do so, he may “opt out” and become a “permanent resident” of Israel. The act of “opting out” is a declaration that he does not desire to become an Israeli citizen, which may be made at the date upon which he is to receive his “oleh’s” cer tificate — prior to that date or within three months of that date, provided he is still then a foreign national. He may similarly waive his right so to declare by notification to the Ministry of Interior. Israeli law recognises and permits dualnationality. How ever, it is to be emphasised that the question to be ascer tained by potential new 'im migrants is whether the coun try of their current nation ality (if they are interested in retaining that nationality) similarly recognises the con cept of dual nationality. Although the conferment of Israel nationality upon the “oleh” is an award not pre ceded by any formal applica tion nor involving any oath of allegiance or other formal procedure, nevertheless some nations and legal systems still consider its acquisition an act of expatriation, resulting in revocation or deprivation of original nationality, or in the limitation or cancellation of certain rights incidental to such nationality, such as pen sion rights. NafionaBities However, the holder of a permanent residence visa will find that he is deprived of certain fundamental rights, while still incurring funda mental duties. Thus, for ex ample, he is obliged to serve the Israel Defence Forces, though he may not vote in Knesset elections (while he may vote in Municipal elections) nor may he serve in many civil ser vice or governmental posts, other than under special con tractual and other arrange ments. The main concessions granted to the “oleh” by statute are those in the spheres of direct and indirect taxation. There are five “direct” taxes from which the new immi grant or temporary resident is exempt, either wholly or par tially. In the first place, income tax: the concession, which ex tends over a period of 42 months, commencing from the “oleh's” date of entry into the country, takes the follow ing form: no income tax is levied upon income of up to IL 1,200 per month for the first 18 months, IL700 per month for the next twelve months, and IL200 per month for the 12 months thereafter. Concessions This concession is granted both to “olim” and tempor ary resident. These exemp tions are granted over and above the regular exemptions granted under law, such as children’s allowances. Thus, to benefit fully from the tax exemption, the immi grant should earn a taxable income as soon after his arrival as possible. With regard to income ac crued abroad and merely transferred to Israel, the new immigrant is exempt from in come tax on such funds dur ing a period of seven years from the date of “aliya”. The new immigrant is ex empted from capital gains tax on a capital profit realised upon the sale of an asset which he owned outside Israel prior to his “aliya”, where he has sold it within seven years from the date of that “aliya”. The new immigrant is partially exempted from pro perty and war compensation tax, which is a tax payable annually by owners of pro- j perty. Land fees An “oleh” or temporary resident does not pay land registration fees upon the purchase or long-term lease of a residential house, or apartment or business or pre mises to be used for both residential and industrial pur-1 poses, nor any other fees de-[ manded by the Land Regis-1 trar in connection with such I purchase or long-term lease, including the registration of a mortgage taken as a guaran tee for the payment of the house, apartment or business premises. This concession, which is valid for one purchase or long-term lease, as above, is granted for a period of 5 years from the date of entry into the country and may be exercised within one year of emigration to Israel. The con cession also attaches to the purchase of vacant land, with in certain “areal minima”, for the purpose of constructing an apartment or business pre mises of the kind mentioned above. The property of an oleh that is situated outside Israel at the time of his death, and was owned by him before this “aliya”, is not subject to Estate Duty in Israel. Travel fax There are two categories of indirect taxation, exemption j from which will be greatly jj welcomed by “olim”. The Knesset has created a lucrative source of revenue through its Foreign Travel Tax legislation. However, both “olim” and temporary residents are ex empt from this tax for three years from their date of entry into the country, with the proviso that temporary resi dents must either pay for their travel ticket in foreign currency or purchase their ticket abroad. The other general category is customs duty and purchase tax. The general rule is that im migrants and temporary resi dents are exempt from these duties, fully or partially, or household goods purchased for personal use and machin ery for professional employ, usually up to certain specified amounts, whether purchased in Israel or abroad for a period of three years from their date of “aliya” — with the exception of a motor-car where the privileged period is two years. These concessions may also apply to tourists who pur chase a home fn Israel and spend a part of every yeai therein, upon special applica tion to the Director of Cus toms. It should be noted that a 25% “ad valorem” C.I.F levy, and, in any event, not less than IL1 per kg. weight is payable on a car, upon the expiration of one year of the (Continued on page 11) IMMIGRANT AND LAW (Continued from page 10) purchase of the car by tem porary residents, and imme diately upon purchase of the car by “olim”. The final group of conces sions to “olim” whose source is statutory in that concerning foreign currency. Currency “Oleh” may hold and im port foreign currency for a period of ten consecutive years from the date of his “aliya”. During this period, he may transfer abroad or within Israel, to certain cate gories of persons, under cer tain conditions, any amount of such foreign currency and may withdraw it in cash only when leaving the coun try. The currency may be held in hard cash for the first six months of residence in Israel and thereafter must be de posited in an authorised bank, where it can earn in terest at a current rate of 7% per annum. The interest earned on such deposits is exempt from income tax for a period of seven years. The “oleh” is entitled, dur ing his first ten years of resi dence in the country, to con vert back into foreign cur rency an amount of Israel pounds not exceeding that amount which he has con verted from foreign currency during such period of residence in Israel. The Israel legislature has gone very far to facilitate initial immigrant absorption, in the face of a paralysing defence budget, and at the risk of fostering a degree of “discrimination” between “olim” and the rest of the populace. article_text: Soviet immigrant is winning physicist JERUSALEM: Five years after immigrating to Israel from the Soviet Union, Dr Lazar Friedland has walked off with a top prize for his doctoral thesis in physics — written in Hebrew — at the Hebrew Uni versity of Jerusalem. HE HAS also won a fencing com petition, has represented the Hebrew University at a scientific symposium abroad, and says, “Israel has been good to me.” His teacher. Prof Felix Dothan, says the prize-winning thesis on “Ionization and Excitation of Gases in Strong Electrostatic and Laser Radiation Fields” pioneered a new theoretical approach to un derstanding the behavior of gases. It won Lazar Friedland the University’s Aharon Katzir Prize for 1976. an award given the best Ph.D. disser tation in science. About his important contribution to the field of electrical gas discharge physics, Lazar Friedland says: “I am interested in the role of electrons in electrical and laser-induced gas discharges. By using new theoretical methods to compute information about these discharges, we can an swer many open questions in this field of physics.” Prof Dothan adds, “To simplify this interesting and original topic, we can say, rather, poetically, that Lazar Friedland was playing with electrons — what we call the Monte Carlo method in mathematics. “By tracing the actions and re actions of many electrons, open to several kinds of activities (collision with a molecule or an atom, for example), one can see not only what happens to each electron, but what happens to the. gas itself. The compu ter, having enough time and patience to trace millions of electrons, brings us to some very interesting results. “If the gas is exposed to an enor mously intense electromagnetic field like that found in the focus of a laser beam, an extraordinary phenomenon happens, one that is known ex perimentally. But there are aspects of the theoretical understanding of it that Lazar Friedland was the first in the world to find out. His work was recognized by people who understand, andhe received the Katzir Prize.” After completing his master’s degree at Vilnus University in Lithuania, in 1970, Lazar wanted to. continue towards his doctorate. “Even though my grades were high, I wasn’t accepted to do my doctorate. Firstly, because the authorities knew I was a Jew. And secondly, they also knew I wanted to come to Israel.” Lazar applied for an exit visa in 1961 he received that visa in 1971. An only son, Lazar immigrated to Israel in 1971 with his mother, a pharmacist, who now also lives in Jerusalem. “I left the USSR,” Lazar went on, “without knowing for sure that I would be able to continue my studies. But as soon as I arrived I began speaking to people about my field and the possibility of further study. I was accepted to every university I applied to here in Israel.” .AFTER A THREE month ulpan in Ashdod, and a three month ulpan in Jerusalem, Lazar had mastered the Hebrew language. In fact his doc torate is written in Hebrew. “I think.” Lazar said smiling, “that learning the language was the most important factor in my rapid ad justment to life in Israel. After four months. I could read a newspaper. And once you can communicate, you’re really on your way.” Besides Hebrew, Lazar speaks English. Russian and Lithuanian. “I knew very little about Israel before I came here. I read virtually nothing. But I did listen to Israel Radio which I enjoyed much.” Upon arrival in Israel. Lazar and his mother were .taken to an ab sorption center in Ashdod and, shortly thereafter, they moved to their present apartment in Jerusalem which they found through the help of the Jewish Agency. Lazar, who has published both in Israel and the USSR, is pleased with the educational facilities here. “Everyone has helped me very much. I came not knowing Hebrew at all. and my professors, Pinhas Avivi and Felix Dothan, took me in like family. I am very grateful to them both I am satisfied here. Israel has been good to me. Everything has gone smoothly and easily. Most of my frien ds here are old friends from Lithuania, a very special place. Everyone I knew in Lithuania had a Jewish background — and almost all of my friends there decided to come on aliva. So now we are here together.” When asked his thoughts about the “typical Israeli” and the painful problem of so often being considered an outsider, Lazar said, “Israelis are a strange breed. Because they have always lived in Israel, among other Jews, they feel their Judaism less strongly than a Jew who comes from the outside. “Talking to an Israeli about anti semitism is like trying to tell someone what soup is if he has never eaten it. But I feel very comfortable here.” BESIDES HIS career as a brilliant young physicist. Lazar has quite an interesting hobby. He fences. Starting in the USSR as a child, Lazar con tinued with this sport here in Israel and he placed first throughout Israel in the Hapoel competitions. Besides fencing, Lazar enjoys swimming and tennis. Travel abroad also interests Lazar. He has been to France. England, and Holland, where he was the represen tative of the Hebrew University at a scientific symposium in 1975. “I gave a talk there, in English,” Lazar continued, “on part of my doc torate. I loved being in Europe, but Israel is my home.” Lazar has served in the Israeli ar my and fought in the Yom Kippur War. “Although war is indeed a horror, being in the army during the Yom Kippur War was a very positive ex perience for me. To really know a nation you must see it in a difficult situation. When something ex traordinary happens in Israel, the people are at their best. I’m talking about incidents such as Munich and Entebbe.” When asked about feelings of nostalgia for Lithuania. Lazar smiled. “Sure I long for the places where I lived. Lithuania was really beautiful. But I have no friends left there now. They are all here. And that changes things. I really love Jerusalem.”

article_text: A gypsy immigrant living in Israel “I felt small in Hungary — almost as if I wasn’t even a person. Here I am free.” Not an unusual statement perhaps from a refugee from Central Europe — and to make such a statement in Israel is still not so unusual. But if the speaker is a Gypsy, an actress, and a new im migrant as well — then she has something special to say. After all, there aren’t too many Gypsies living in the Jewish State. Ona Saloman, married to a Hungarian Jewish playwright, left her native country when her husband was blacklisted for “political” reasons. She made her own claim to the blacklist when refusing to act in a Russian play which she considered bad, ar tistically and ideologically. That was in 1974. Here in Israel for a year now, the intervening times were hard for her and her husband Paul. Ona reflects that most of her life has been spent in putting the lie to stereotypes about her people, and about the Jewish people of her husband too. She came from an ex ceptional family. “My grandfather was a Gypsy par excellence,” she recalls. Continuing in near perfect Hebrew, Ona relates, “Nature and the real world, not the laws of men — they were what mattered for him. ” Ona’s mother an Opera singer, Magda Varga, even became popular in Italy af ter performances there. As a young Gypsy girl Ona had a comfortable childhood replete with a normal Hungarian up bringing in a large city that did not include caravans or fortune telling but it was a tense time because she never felt at home. “I especially remember feeling like the Jews — without a home. You see, Hungary, and especially Debrecen, was world famous as a centre for anti Semitism. As a girl I remember all the horrible stories about the Nazis which later turned out to be doubly true because they applied to the Gypsies as well.” But Ona remembers bet ter stories. She relates Gypsy history and lore as if it was a part of her own life story. Like the Jews, the Gyp sies at times during their history yearned for a homeland, but their economic base was un sound, being essentially a nation of small craftsmen and wanderers. By the late 1930’s, in spite of not paying taxes to local governments and living mostly by suffrance, they did manage to front a king to the world and put their case before the League of Nations. But King Janusz Kiviek was fighting the tide of Nazism. His idea to shift a nation of jugglers, horse traders, tinsmiths, and a few score lawyers to an island somewhere in Polynesia, was stillborn. Tens of thousands of Gypsies were ex terminated by Hitler. . The few thousand who survived Auschwitz and other German horrors soon abandoned the idea of a Romany state, but not then notions of freedom and the belief in the sanctity of nature. “I suppose very few Gyp sies have taken the course I have chosen, although many have found freedom in Western Europe and even in America,” Ona says. Ona Saloman in a Jerusalem setting. “But here in Israel it’s very special. The Israelis have a lot of un derstanding, but not by any means in a patronizing way. They take things and people purely on face value.” Ona has been intensively studying Hebrew since the day of her arrival. She has reached a point now where she will begin an acting job, in Hebrew, this July with the Beersheva Theatre. In Hungary she acted in Shakespeare, Checkhov, Brecht, and Genet. In Israel she will soon be doing much the same, but in Hebrew. The people in Beersheva were so impressed that they are anxious for her to do a series of poetry readings and songs in both Hebrew and Hungarian. “Throughout history Gypsies have been a sym 'bol of freedom,” Ona says. “I feel that Israel is giving us back something that Europe stole and nearly destroyed—ourselves. ”
article_heading: A gypsy immigrant living in Israel

article_text: PROTEST AGAINST ANTI-IMMIGRANT ADVERTISEMENT FOR CLEANERS MELBOURNE: Ten migrant workers employed at the Laurens Street plant of the Victorian Railways have protested to the Migrant Workers' Conference Committee about an advertisement which appeared recently in a Greek language newspaper. The advertisement read "Men cleaners wanted. They must be Australian citizens. Apply Jensen House, 339 Swanston St., Melbourne." In their letter the workers say "Australia's immigration policy does not require a person to be a citizen before he can get a job. In any case citizenship cannot be obtained unless a person has been in Australia for three years. "Jensen House policy on employment clearly discriminates against non- naturalised immigrants, especially the new arrivals. It is grossly unjust and preposterous that one cannot clean Jensen House's offices or toilets unless one is a male and holds a certificate of Australian citizenship." In their letter the migrant workers asked for public condemnation and withdrawal of the Jensen House advertisement, and expressed their belief that the Greek newspaper concerned should publicly apologise for its oversight and join the protest against Jensen House. The Migrant Workers' Conference Committee is reporting this matter to the Victorian Trades Hall Council, the Miscellaneous Workers' Union, the Minister for Immigration and Labor, and the Committee on Discrimination in Employment. Jensen House is occupied by the Department of Manufacturing Industry.

article_text: 89-Jarige immigrant Van Delft naar Blacktown BLACKTOWN, NSW — De 89-jarige Han van der Water is uit Delft in Australie gearriveerd, waar hij nu bij zijn enige zoon in het nabij Sydney gelegen Black town woont. Zijn schoondochter Rose van der Water-Snaith heeft hem opgehaald en reisde met hem in drie etappes per vliegtuig naar Sydney. De eerste vlucht ging naar Teheran, waar drie dagen gerust werd. En vervolgens, telkens met een onderbreking van drie da gen, vloog hij naar Bang kok, Hong Kong en ten slotte naar Sydney. Deze voorzorg werd genomen vanwege de hoge leeftijd van de immigrant. Rose Waters, zoals de verengelste naam van de schoondochter luidt, was 7 jaar gelederi met haar man ook al eens in Delft, maar toen wilde Han van der Water nog niet mee naar Australie. Nu wilde hij echter graag, omdat hij zich zo alleen voelde. Han van der W-ater werkte jarenlang als amb tenaar bij de Rijksgebou wendienst en woonde op een unieke plaats in Ne derland, namelijk het Binnenhof. Ongeveer 17 jaar geleden verhuisde hij naar de Wateringse Vest in Delft. Hij heeft daar de afge lopen 10 jaar — na het overlijden van zijn derde vrouw — in zijn eentje ge woond. Het ging goed tot hij in Augustus zijn spaar bankboekje en andere waardepapieren verloor en daarover erg van streek raakte. Via de Delftse PTT kwam het terug en in feite op aandringen van de direc teur van het postkantoor ging de reis naar Austra lie door. In Blacktown zag Han van der Water nu ook voor het eerst zijn vier achter kleinkinderen. Rose Waters vertelde: 'Hij ontmoette er ook weer zijn eerste vrouw, van wie hij gescheiden is. Het is de moeder van mijn man. Mijn schoonmoeder woont al 20 jaar dichtbij in Rooty Hill'.

article_text: U.K. IMMIGRANT LAWS Commonwealth 'still favoured' PEEBLES, Scotland, Sunday (AAP). —Forty- eight Australians and 68 New Zealanders had been refused admission to Britain between January and August this year, Britain's Foreign Secretary, Sir Alec Douglas-Home, said in Peebles last night, the Press As- sociation reported. During the same period, 108,800 Australians and 25,704 Nesv Zealanders had entered Britain. Sir Alec was refuting charges before a meeting of Scottish Young Conser- vatives that Britain was not eager to admit Common- wealth citizens or that they found any difficulty in coming. It was not true that they would be reduced to the status of aliens from Jan- uary 1 when Britain joined the Common Market and new immigration rules came into force. Sir Alec said it was claimed that Common- wealth citizens would now have to take second place to nationals of EEC coun- tries.  Sir Alec Douglas-Home  "Certainly the European Economic Community is a free-travel area in which there will be a free move- ment of labour. Many important privileges "Unlike the Common- wealth situation, however, there is no evidence that large numbers of people from other European members of the commun- ity wish to come and settle permanently in Britain. "None of this, however, affects the many important privileges which Common- wealth citizens enjoy and which EEC nationals and aliens do not". They would continue to enjoy full civic privileges such as the right to vote and be able to fill posts not open to nliens, such as the armed forces. Any Commonwealth citizen whose mother or father was born in the United Kingdom would be free to come and go as he pleased. They would not have to complete land- ing and embarkation cards or report to the police. Sir Alec, referring to the number of Australians and New Zealanders re- fused admission this year, said, "They surely refute the charge that we are not eager to take members of the old Commonwealth, or that they find any diffi- culty in coming. "The important privil- eges which I have men- tioned, none of which will be enjoyed by aliens and citizens of the EEC coun- tries, are a mark of the value which we continue to place on the Common- wealth relationship and are in no way, limited by our membership of the Euro- pean community'.

article_text: IMMIGRANT WORKERS Immigrant Workers — 'next to the aboriginals they are the most alienated section of the Australian population' by Alan Matheson 'In the last 25 years almost 1 million non British migrants have joined the Australian working class and, more specifically, its in dustrial section. Some continue to arrive, others have been here for a while, many are becoming workers for the first time ... Pre dominantly southern European, they constit ute unquestionably the majority of the lower Daid workers, of those on or nearest the Dovertv line, of those first and hardest hit by even the mildest economic recession. Next to the Abor iginals they are the most alienated section of Australia's population they occupy a distinct ly inferior socio-economic and ethnic position'. So runs a draft statement circulating at pre sent within the Australian trade union move ment. The statement is a working proposal for the setting up of a migrant worker conference conducted by migrant workers to be held later this year. It's probably one of the most sig nificant attempts by immigrant workers in Australia in their struggle for social justice. For Dr Parmer, addressing a development conference of the World Council of Churches, 'social justice reflected in greater equality of opportunity, a more egalitarian social order, a diffusion of economic and political power from the few to the many, is the most important element of self-development'. Well so what, you may say? Migrants are here aren't they? They're not starving out there in the big Underdeveloped lands of beggars, bulging tum mies and ricketty starving children are they? You're right they're not. But like others in the world community they're denied justice, their rights are trampled on, they're exploited, and equality and human dignity have as much meaning for them as for the sufferer in the liberation struggle in Angola or Mozambique. It probably takes the senseless shaking of steel fences and punctured factory walls to prompt us to reflection on the 'development dilemma' of the frustrated, angry Greek or Turkish worker caught up in the deadly power lessness of the assembly line at Fords. Immigrant workers in Australia call them selves the most alienated section next to the aboriginal, of Australia's population. A meeting of migrant workers and church men in Europe saw migration in terms of 'the exploitation of a sub-proletariat by the host country, the destruction — without replace ment — of cultural standards and social struct ures in the country of origin and the loss of dignity and disruption of family life for the migrant worker'. Australian migrant workers would agree. Migration is one of those things which high lights the dependent relationships between countries. It further breaks down the so called exclusive boundaries between 'developed' and 'under developed' countries. As Pamela Gruber suggested last year: 'if we recognize social justice as an over arching goal in development we have the possibility to recognize once and for all that under-development is not to be found ex clusively in what we lump together as the Third World ... it is to be found throughout the world.' Commenting on the recent troubles at the Ford factory in Broadmeadows a leader of one of the migrant communities said that migrant workers resented their second class image and treatment...'these people are tired of being treated as factory fodder'. So set in the context of social justice those agencies concerned with development should perhaps be giving serious consideration to their role with the struggle of the migrant worker for equality and dignity. Already these same agen cies have indicated by their support for blacks in Australia, that their vision and concept of development is not tied to static concepts of 'developed' and 'under-developed' countries. The migrant workers conference aims to bring together workers, especially migrants to discuss (preferably in their own language): 1 . Migrant problems and their views on wages and conditions, on methods of struggle, on measures to facilitate their involvement in the affairs and leadership of their unions and job organization. 2. The mass consciousness of the migrant workers' position in the labour movement and the Australian society. Will it come off remains to be seen. The organizers are in need of support. This is an area in which the aid agencies might well help. It was at a 1972 meeting that the Australian Council for Overseas Aid was confronted with the challenge by Pamela Gruber from the World Council of Churches: 'whilst it is less embarrassing for those of us who come from rich nations and from the comparatively rich within those nations, to look at the main frustrations of the con ditions of underdevelopment in the Third World ... unless we grasp the situations at home and hopefully, tackle them, then we have little hope of being part of the enab ling process that will be involved in the resolution of underdevelopment outside our national boundaries'. Migrant workers may well ask the aid agen cies to stand with them, to indicate a measure of support in their struggle for justice and dignity and rights, a struggle which is little different from those already receiving support of aid agencies in a score of other countries.

article_text: Naambord immigrant uit park verwiiderd Burgemeester 'veeltedruk' MELBOURNE, Vic — Het naambord met de noam van de 41-jarige John van der Loo in het park op de hoek van Pascoe Vale Road en Murphy Stree*- te Oak Park is verdwenen. Dit gebeurde niet en 'so we wiped the record clean' ' aldus gemeentesecretaris Smiley. Hij zei ook nog, dat het niet alleen de burgemees ter was die voor dit besluit stemde. article_text: Inaezonden ' --: -?-vv:- fJ-rT vergrijzende iimrigrant door HENK EK Men wordt er wel eens moedeloos onder als men ziet hoe de mogelijkheden om een weekblad in de Nederiandse taal hier in Australie telkens weer op tijd te doen verschijnen zonder de nodige inkomsten uit advertenties of dergelijke om dat allemaal te .kunnen bekostigen. Wanneer je dan praat met Nederlanders — al of niet genaturaliseerd — die op latere Ieeftijd naar dit land zijn gekomen en nu tegen de 60 of meer beginnen te (open, dan merk je toch wel dat er veel behoefte bestaat aan contact met iets dat in de vertrouwde taal berichtgeving verzorgt. Meestal heef t men zich met de Bngelse taal aardig kunnen behelpen en trok men op met de Australiers. De Nederlander is er altijd trots op geweest onafhankelijk te zijn en het te kunnen 'mixen' met de Aussies en immigranten uit andere landen. Maar plotseling schijnt dat allemaal niet zo vlot meer te verlopen. Men gaat het moeilijk vinden om zich in de aangeleerde taal uit te drukken en de plaatselijke kranten, radio en televisie schijnen ook niet meer het nodige vertier te geven dat men in de avonduren wel eens nodig heefl om een beetje op verhaal te komen. Men krijgt plotseling een vreemd verlangen naar het land van oorsprong of naar -een gesprek in de vanouds vertrouwde taal, een leuke kwinkslag of een goed verhaal. Als men het zich kan veroorloven dan maakt men een reisje naar Europa en ontmoet men familieleden en oude vrienden, ook al zijn die dan niet zo talrijk meer als men die gedachthad. ? ?',/? Er zijn er ook velen — te veel eigenlijk — die de roep van het vaderland niet langer kunnen weerstaan en terugkeren. Sommigen lukt het om zich daar weer te vestigen, anderen kunnen het ook daar niet meer wennen en trachten er dan het beste van te maken of , keren uiteindelijk toch weer. naar Australie terug. Maar in ieder geval hebben zij zich kunnen overtuigen wat nu eigenlijk de oplossing is Voor een dreigende vereenzaming, met terug? Velen echter geven niet toe aan de verleiding terug te gaan vanwege de kinderen die zich hier als 'dinkum Aussies' gevestigd hebben. En zij hebben het moeilijk en geven ruiterlijk toe dat een krant als-de DAW een kostbaar iets voor hen is. Er zijn hier in Australie her en der heel wat Nederlandse verenigingen waar men contact met elkaar kan hebben en waar ingezien wordt hoe noodzakelijk het is voor de ouderen onder ons de band te behouden. ? Zij geven dan zelfs een maandblad uit met een p r o g r a m m a over de gebeurtenissen en wat nieuws. Men komt dan tot de ontdekking dat dit heel wat geld kost. Maar vaak wordt dan grif door medeleden aangeboden door middel van advertenties de kosten te dekken. Dit vindt dus in klein verband plaats voor bepaalde groepen waar beseft wordt, dat men te'samen iets moet doen om het leven van de vergrijsde immigrant en ook jongeren een beetje kleur te geven. Dat is echter niet genoeg. Er zijn talrijke immigranten van Nederlandsen bloede over het gehele land verspreid die dezelfde morele steun nodig hebben maar te verspreid gevestigd zijn om hierin een aandeel te hebben. Door middel van het nu bijna 25 jaar bestaande weekblad Dutch-Australian Weekly is dat tot nu toe mogelijk geweest met steun van de adverteerders. Met 12 tot 16 pagina's wist men zo'n beetje. voor 'elck wat wils' te brengen. Doch die steun is grotendeels weggevallen. Vreemd! Want zij die regelmatig adyerteren hebben ondervonden dat hun advertenties wel degelijk gelezen worden en dat het zoden aan de dijk zet. Het mes snijdt dus van 2 kanten. .'? ? In groepsverband is men zich er dus wel degelijk van bewust dat — in kleine kring — geholpen moet 'worden'om' berichtgeving mogelijk te maken: - Is dat nu eigenlijk niet een beetje kortzichtig? Kunnerr wij met elkaar nu niet zorgen voor de financiele steun noodzakelijk om de DAW in stand te houden en uit te breiden, schrijvers aan te trekken en zelfs weer het feuilleton — erg populair — regelmatig te kunnen doen verschijnen en ook de jongere immigrant te kunnen blijven interesseren. Laten we er eens goed over nadenken. Zoals de zeeman over de foto op de voorpagina'van het nummer van 13 Augustus schreef, dat hij trots was van Nederlandse afkomst te zijn na het zien van dit staaltje van technisch kunnen. Er moet meer van dergelijk materiaal in dit weekblad verschijnen en dat hangt van de oud-Nederlander in Australie af. Ais eerder gezegd, denk er eens over na en dit niet alleen, doe er wat aan. PARRAMATTA, NSW

article_text: G3 B PI S M ® H door MARTIN HULSTEIJN ATHERTON, Qld — In 1884 vochten honderden moedige pioniers slechts gewapend met houwelen, zich een weg door maagdeligk oerwoud voor de bouw van de spoorweg van Cairns naar de Atherton Tablelands. Zij groeven 15 tunnels door rotswanden en bouwden series houten bruggen en viadukten over raviinen. Sinds die tijd is er niet veel ver&nderd. Goed, de romantische stoom locomotieven staan als museum stukken in stadjes en hebben plaats gemaakt voor diesel elektrischen maar de houten viadukten en treinstellen zijn er nog, de overwegen zijn nog onbewaakt en de wissels nog handbediend. Bij de in- en uitgang van het station worden kaartjes geknipt en over een afstand van 100 kilometer driemaal gecontro leerd en afgestreept op een indrukwekkende lijst. Bij vertrek loopt de station chef met een koperen bel te zwaaien. Op piepkleine stationnetjes in het 'nergens' belt de machinist de centrale op door heftig aan een handeltje te draaien. In Kuranda rennen de mannen massaal naar de 'pub' om even eenpaar biertjes weg te werken. Geen wonder dat de rit over dezelfde 100 kilometers naar Atherton bijna vier wren duurt. Wat ons betreft, behoeft men dit stuk spoorweg geschiedenis niet te moderniseren. Het 'easy going' boemeltje beviel ons uitstekend. Vooral de eerste 34 kilometer naar Kuranda zijn een droom. i Het treintje slingert zich door weelderige jungle en langs diepe ravijnen omhoog. Het uitzicht over het dal en de koraalzee is onvergetelijk. Bij watervallen en uitzichten in rotskloven wordt vaart gemin derd en bij de Barron Falls is er een (otostop. Langs de Barron River is het groen en fris maar hogerop in de vlakte, geel en dor. In het droge land verrijzen nu honderden metershoge termieten heuvels. Bij Mareeba, waar het land geirrlgeerd wordt, zijn uitgestrekte tabaksplantages, om Atherton zijn het de maisvelden en pinda plantages, die het aanzien van het landschap bepalen. Als boerenknecht Het avontuur heeft de 85-jarige uit Westzaan afkomstige Alex Steenstra altijd in het bloed gezeten. Alex werkte als kind van 11 jaar bij Molenaars kindermeel fabriek en droomde er van om eens met een van de schepen, die hij door het Noordzee kanaal zag varen, mee te gaan naar overzee. Op zijn twintigste jaar las Alex een advertentie waarin om boerenknechten voor Queensland werd gevraagd. Leep als hij was, trad hij voor enkele uren in dienst bij boer Piet Koopman, vroeg vervolgens een paspoort aan waarbij hij als beroep boerenknecht opgaf, ging met dit document gewapend solliciteren en werd aangenomen. Voor de eerste wereldoorlog uitbrak landde de jonge Zaanse Fries in het vreedzame Queens land. Over zijn belevenissen in zijn eerste Australische jaren zou Alex een boek kunnen schrijven. Hij tuinierde op een onbewoond eiland. Werd bij het.baden door een haai aangevallen en verloor bijna het been. Wegen waren er toen nog niet, alleen paarderoutes. Alex werkte bij de bouw van de spoorweg. Op betaaldag kropen de rauwbonken op een locomotief en reden naar een 'pub' waar zij zich met rum lieten vol lopen. Alex dronk niet maar stuurde zijn geld naar zijn moeder in Westzaan. In zijn brieven Het hij moeder de groeten doen een Trijntje Harrewijn, een buurmeisje, op wie hij altijd al verliefd was. Oude liefde De liefdfc was wederzijds, Trijntje vroeg Alex terug te komen om haar te trouwen. In 1919 traden Alex en Trijntje in het huwelijk en besloten naar Queensland te gaan. Het zou tot na de dood van Trijntjes moeder in 1928 duren, voordat zij vertrokken. Hun fouragezaak in Heemskerk gaven zij op en gingen op weg, het avontuur tegemoet. Ze hadden inmiddels twee kinderen. Tot de depressie in 1934 bleven de Steenstra's in Queensland en gingen toen weer terug. Met nun kinderen van 5 en 9 jaar liepen ze 1.500 kilometer naar Brisbane. Zij beschouwden deze mars als een laatste gelegenheid Queensland goed in zich op te nemen. In Nederland roddelde men dat de stakkers liepen omdat er geen geld was voor de trein. Deze laster werd in de kiem gesmoord toen de Steenstra's een hotel op de Prins Hendrikkade in Amsterdam kochten. In 1936 werd het verlangen naar Queensland echter zo hevig, dat zij besloten om terug te gaan. Nu voor altijd! Alex Steenstra is nog kwiek en helder van geest. Door de ziekte van Trijntje zullen ze hun 60 jarige huwelijksfeest volgend jaar wel niet mogen beleven. Tot na de Tweede Wereldoorlog waren zij de enige Nederlanders in dit deel van Australie. Zij spreken nog vloeiend hun moedertaal en zijn in hart en nieren 'Dutch' gebleven. WiJ zullen Alex en Trijntje niet meer zien maar nooit vergeten. P.S. - Wij kregen zojuist bericht, dat Trijntje Steenstra op 19 Juli op 85jarige leeftijd is overleden.

article_text: [IIFE STYLE}  '"GOOD UVINO _ __ Wine figured in Greek immigrant's dream By MICHAEL FOSTER -i HE first conscious decision on the project was that one day he would own a restaurant in Canberra, the second was that he would start buying wines For it. They were so closely related as to have almost been one and the second decision was the sooner acted upon by John Praxoulis, now the owner of Zorba's restaurant, of its considerable wine cellar and of various other properties and enterprises in the city of his adoption. The Greek-born restaurateur says, and his menus and wine lists tend to confirm, that because of his buying policy he can put forward some very good wines and foods at very good prices. Certainly any eating place, and there are several, which survives in the fickle and competitive Canberra eating environment for. five years has solid public support. The man is ebullient and hyperactive, and sometimes irascible, and an interview is an athletic experience for mind and body as he rushes from subject to subject, from cellar to cool room, from city centre to suburban home. For he wants to tell it all, and show it all. There is a deceptive portliness about him because in fact he is a keen fitness man. His house was built where it was because there is parkland in which he and his neighbours run. It has its own covered, year-round pool, its own small gym and sauna and a section of yard where roof tiles are delivered in large lots for he is also a karate exponent. It was not disclosed whether this interest in the martial art arose from the time when he was everything in his restaurant from cook to cleaner, and perhaps bouncer, or whether it is a relaxation. If it is the latter it is a peculiar one because during the interview which assembled this piece there were stitches across the left temple where a lump resulting from contact between head and tiles had been removed. But beneath all the activity, or at its centre perhaps, there must be an area of calm and logic where decisions are mulled and culled and finally made. Decisions There was the decision to own a restaurant, followed immediately by that to begin then to buy the wins to provide the future libations. The house, set on a large block of about 1.5 hectares, was not built until all the surrounding blocks had been built c6h and the artchitect knew what had to be overlooked or excluded by the Praxoulis residence. There was the decision to learn butchering as well as cooking and to put a cool room in the restaurant so that meat bought in bulk was properly hung and butchered to the requirement of the menu offered. There was the round of jobs undertaken once he had qualified as a chef. This gave him a wide repertoire which included international delights as well as "good, plain Australian cooking". There arc the alterations being made to the restaurant which will enable better use of space and, at the same time, make better use of staff, and the fact that all internal joinery has been prefabricated so that it can be done with minimal trading loss. It is possible that Saturday night diners who eturn Wednesday :vening will dine in two iistinctivcly different restaurants, but in the same place. There is the decision to keep pysically fit as a counter to the debilitating nature of the work he does and the odd hours it requires and the determination to keep in contact with his family. And that was another decision. The house is where it is so that he can make the journey in a relatively few minutes. He does it several times a day and the atmosphere of the home reflects the balance between the ebullient master and the quiet calm of the mistress. Mrs Helen Praxoulis became so after an overseas tour by John some years ago. She is French-born of Greek parents and they met in the Greek Islands in 1968. She is now the mothr of their four children, a boy and three girls, and hostess at planned functions or unplanned visitations such as mine. There was first something slightly obscene for someone like me to be quaffing a 1971 Wolf Blass cabernet shiraz in the middle of a Canberra spring afternoon, but the warmth of the hostess, the enthusiasm of the host and the fine wine soon transformed the whole experience into a great pleasure. It was a wine for fine food, and in their way the olives and the superb imported fetta were just that. The host insisted, however, that there is Australian fetta which is as good. He had bought the fetta in the course of a business deal. He did not say but it obviously had been both good business and good business politics. It was also good cheese. Then it was an equally exciting imported port, old and glowing on the palate and the afternoon. And always the talk, whatever its several tangents, returned to the wines. Followina the decision to buy, made 10 years ago and five years before the restaurant became reality, John Praxoulis began sampling wines, talking to evervone he knew who liked wine and whose appreciations he approved. They included sellers, good livers and, whenever possible, winemakers. Coupled with his own tastes they enabled him to assemble a cellar which makes this enthusiast drool. It includes some imported wine, French and Mediterranean and including Greek naturally enough, but the bulk is good Australian, both because he likes it and because he believes Australians, which he is now, should support their local product when it it worthy. It includes, purely as examples, 1963 Hardy's which he bought at about $2.50 and which he offers for about $6 Lindemans Hunter River claret of 1964 and burgundy of 1961: 1969 D'Arenburg, Killawarra shiraz and cabernet savignon from the mid-60s. Most of these he bought at about $2. They arc worth a hell of a lot more now, and certainly more on the open market than he charges. There are also some even better lines which he does not list but he delights in meeting special requests when they are made (and where the cellar can) and takes some lines off as reserves as his stock diminishes and regular and respected customers express their preferences. Mr Praxoulis (left). Miss Maria Stavropoulos and Mr Bernard Sertillanges, of his restaurant staff, sample a wine as a possible cellaring prospect. s_ Naturally enough the restaurant has a larger throughput of wines than his earlier buying could meet so his cellar is run on a three-tier system. There are the wines that go in and out fairly swiftly, including the house lines there are those which he bought in the years leading up to his opening and for a year or two afterwards and which are used less freely and there are those which are going into the cellar now for use only after several years spent gathering dust, age and almost certainly value. Independent It is a system which the man has envisaged ever since the boy of nearly 16 arrived in Australia 1950. It was August 14 and the next day the boy was in Canberra working for a Greek couple in a job which was arranged Crete and for which the father advanced the boy his fare so he would be an independent immigrant. The boy found himself sleeping on the garage floor of his employers' house, working up to 18 hours a day and denied the opportunities offered at the Canberra Technical School because hi employers resented his efforts to gain an education in and of his new land. "I will not say too much about them. They went broke anyway", he says with a smile which shows little malice and certainly no regret. Then came the apprenticeship as a chef and the coooking jobs in Canberra and Wagga Wagga and eventually the restaurant. And through it all has been sustained the spirit and the feeling for life which were so well portrayed in the film which bore the name given the restaurant. There is also a basic realism. The children are getting older and the need to know them better is growing. Family members are now involved in the restaurant (his sister makes the Greek sweets) and the next move, if it eventuates, is for American cousin who is an accountant, to come out to manage the business side of the restaurant while the owner retreats to his first love, the food and the wine. John Praxoulis hopes it does happen because if it does not he sees that in five years, for the sake of j his family and a normal life, he will otherwise have to end his affair with the immigrant boy's dream

article_text: Message du Ministre de l'Immigration a l'occasion du Dimanche de l'Immigrant C ANBERRA. — Mr. Phillip Lynch, MP, ministre fédéral de l'Immigration a fait l'allocution suivante à l'occasion de la célébration nationale du Dimanche de l'immigrant (le 28.11): "La notion de la famille est à la base de la stabilité de la société dans laquelle nous vivons. Et en Australie, alors que nous formons une nation è partir d'un groupement de peuple, la famille nouvellement établie devient la pierre angulaire du succès de notre programme d'immigration. "L'unité est la force, pour la nation ainsi que pour la famille. C'est une vérité permanente mise i l'épreuve chaque jour par les familles australiennes — les anciennes, et celles venant d'outre-mer, qui s'unissent pour affronter les défis de la vie, particulièrement ceux auxquels on doit faire face i l'étranger. "Pour l'immigrant, la mise en commun de l'expérience quotidienne de chaque membre de la famille et la connaissance collective, la sagesse, l'assurance et l'acceptation gagnés de cette manière contribuent i assurer un bon établissement. (Suite à la page 5) DANS LA COLONIE FRANÇAISE LE MESSAGE DE Mr LYNCH (Suite de la première page) "Pour cette rahon, I* programme da l'immigration australienne s'est concentré sur l'immigration des famille». Dam la dernière année financière, 79% de nos {migrants assistés vinrent ici en groupes familiaux. "Depuis la commencement du programme d'immigration d'après-guerre, des succès notables ont été accomplis en réunissant des familles, dont certains de leurs membres eurent A traverser le rideau de fer. (/"Opération Réunion" a sa propre récompense, mais ne satisfait jamais tant qu'il y encore quelques familles séparées, soit par la distance soit par idéologie. "Les familles d'immigrants et les jeunes gens qui sont venus seuls sont encouragés à faire venir d'autre membres de leur famille et leur fiancée pour les rejoindre dans leur vie nouvelle. Avec quelle volonté ils veulent le faire dépend entièrement de leur propre expérience, de la chaleur et la bienveillance avec lesquelles ili sont refus et acceptés par les anciens Australiens, et de leur confiance en l'avenir, laquelle ne peut itre engendrée que s'ils se trouvent heureux parmi nous. "Le but de l'immigration ne consiste pas seulement en un mouvement physique de population d'un pays è un autre. Pour l'atteindre il faut encore faire très attention i la période crudale que nous appelons celle de ''intégration" et qui ne signifie pas un étouffement du nouveau venu par la communauté, mais un apport de sa personnalîté, et de sa contribution, aux attributs è l'héritage de notre communauté. "En fait, ce que l'on recherche est l'intégration des nouveaux arrivés avec l'Australien, et la formation d'une grande famille australienne. Sans intégration satisfaisante, le processus d'immigration n'est pas complet et par là, la construction d'une nation est notoirement retardée. "Bien que la plupart de nos immigrants arrivent en groupes familiaux, ils ont toujours besoin, comme nous-mêmes, de se sentir acceptés dans la grande famille qu'est l'Australie. "Nous devons tous aider cet élan et quelles meilleures avenues que votre foi et les institutions qui en font partie? "Je suis très reconnaissant de l'inestimable et ferme coopération donnée è mon Ministère par les chefs de toutes les organisations religieuses en Australie, sur le plan spirituel et temporel, pour assurer que les besoins et les biterftts individuels de chaque nouveau venu soient compris, satisfaits et épanouis — que l'unité de la famille humaine en Australie soit maintenue et renforcée. "A toutes les congrégations ce week-end, je recommande que durant l'année entière elles se préoccupent de reconnaître individuellement le besoin d'accueillir et d'aider les nouveaux venus — car ce n'est seulement qu'en associé que l'on peut bfitir une meilleure nation". Son prédécesseur, le professeur émerite I. A. Henning, en était le titulaire depuis 1946. addiy/eec e t m » ARRIVEES ET DEPARTS La vedette de cinéma Claudia Cardinale est arrivée à Sydney — "très heureuse d'être ici" dit-elle — la semaine dernière pour tourner, sous la direction de Luigi Zampa, le film "Une jeune fille en Austraite" — un conte sur Plmmigration. Toutefois, dimanche Mlle Cardinale a eu l occasion de retrouver son amie d'école Mlle Mane Baggière qui était venue de Melbourne où elle est rédactrice au service français de Radio-Australie. Mlle Melka Teaton, rédactrice pour les revues parisiennes "Elle" et "Jardin des Modes" est arrivée à Sydney dimanche pour lancer le textile "Celeste" fabriqué par Courtaulds. A la suite d'une, présentation de mode mardi Mlle Treaton s'est rendue' à Melbourne d'où elle rentrera à Paris mardi prochain. S'agissant de la femme australienne Mlle Treaton a déclaré qu'elle l'a trouvait très belle mais, par contre, le maquillage et le style mini laissoient à son avis beaucoup à désirer. LA MISSION DES VINS ET LAROUSSE Au au moment où ou se trouve en Austra- jj e la m i ss i on française d'exportateu d vins - cette mission, conduite par M. J.H. Lefort, e conseiller commercial près l'Ambassade de France, a rencontré, lors d'une dégustation de vins au Wentworth Hôtel U hier soir, le monde vinicole de Sydney , ainsi que bon nombre de nos compatrio- D tes — à l'heurç de cette mission donc, 1 est arrivé de Paris un magnifique volume édité par Larousse: le "Larousse des Vins . En fait c'est le A à Z des vins, de l'Australie à Zwicker, en passant bien naturellement par tous les crus et toutes le s . hautes spécialités françaises, etc. à à raison de 272 P a 8 es illustrations en 9 couleurs selon un nouveau procédé, y c p ompns des cartes et les étiquettes des r viticulteurs les plus connus. Paul Krug, PDG des Champagnes Krug. M. Schyler et ses compagnons se rendront à Melbourne lundi avant de rentrer en France vraisemblablement à la fin de la semaine. Selon un communiqué du département fédéral des Douanes deux films français, des seize films étrangers qui ont été soumis à l'approbation du ministère au mois de janvier dernier, n'ont pas été acceptés tel que. Il s'agit du film "Nathalie" qui, pour des questions de mœurs, n'est pas autorisé à être projeté et "Un rapport secret sur la prostitution" qui a été amputé de deux minutes et quarante secondes. Un festival international de danses folkloriques (intitulé "Come fly with us") avec des groupes de jeunes immigrants de seize pays européens, des Etats-Unis et d'Australie aura lieu au Orpheum Theatre, à Cremorne (Sydney) du 13 au 21 mars prochain. Le concours d'une représentation française n'a pu être, recueilli celte fois encore. Dans le cadre des tournées gastronomiques qui peuvent se faire à Sydney, nous avons déjà mentionné la journée très agréable à la portée de tous ceux qui voudraient quitter la ville, monter à Leura Falls pour déjeuner chez Mme S. Manières au restaurant Fork and View et redescendre par Windsor par exemple. Avec l'ouverture du restaurant Michel à Tahmoor (Sud-Ouest) un nouvel itinéraire s'ajoute aux premiers. Prendre la route de Camden et de Picton et se trouver alors sur la crête de la cordillère, au tiers du chemin Sydney-Canberra. A Tahmoor M. et Mme M. Roser vous accueillent dans leur restaurant coquet, tout blanc, tout neuf. Les spécialités de la maison — on s'en douterait car M. Roser conserve sa ferme d'élevage de volaille — sont les pintades et le faisan — du jeudi au mardi. Dans un très proche avenir Michel's aura son permis pour les vins. Pour les amateurs du petit écran le nom de Jacques de Vigne n'est pas inconnu. Depuis plusieurs années M. de Vigne a dirigé des films à succès pour Channel 9 à Sydney en 1963 un de ses films a représenté l'Australie au Festival de Cannes. La réputation de M. de Vigne n'est plus à faire. Et pourtant voici qu'il se lance à la conquête d'un marché légèrement différent: faire, pour le compte de la société de Mr Geoff Stone "Export Focus" des films TV pour la promotion industrielle de l'Australie et qui seront vendus dans dix pays étrangers avec un auditoire de 500 millions de personnes.
