I was proud, I admit, that one of us new comers to this country. had made it He had overcome the ob stacles that face every immigrant Persever ance and brilliance had paid off- He had climb ed the ladder to be come Secretary of State. ' it was a wonderful tri-' bute to this country, a kind of Horatio Alger story. And it was a re minder to. the. Germans how much talent they had driven out. But then cautious doubts set in.. He was sworn in on a Saturday. His mother held the Bible — but it was the New Testament. Then the house caved in — he married out of the faith, again on a Saturday. My thoughts went back fifty: years ago when an other. Jew became Foreign. Minister in the Weimar Republic of Germany. . His name was Walter Rathenau, a brilliant, an overwhelmingly brilliant man. He was a Jew, but pot a believing Jew. He had severed all connec tions with his people. He had defied, the laws of history, of assimilation and'counterassimilation. CAN’T LEAVE But in the end,. he be came the victim of his trust in the rationality of people and in the open ness of the society of his time. . It is strange that this type' always reaches the top Men v. ho do not want to be Jews,. but-citizens of the world, men who do not want to be. part of the -Jewish people, but. who, nevertheless, have to share its destiny. We surely had too many of them in our turbulent his tory.: Walter Rathenau, an xious, to overcome the iso lation Germany was suf fering after the first World War, signed a treaty with Russia and brought that country back into the fold of nations. .  : And, in. 1922, he was promptly assassinated by Nazis who saw. in him a tool of Communism, an importer of foreign doc trines, and a member of a conspiracy to establish a Jewish hegemony over tiie German people. He died as a Jew and be was burled as a Jew. Fifty years ago, the Russians had an interest in accommodating Ger many in order to come back to the family of na tions. .Nothing came out of it for Germany from this new founded friend ship, but plenty for Russia. Today Henry Kissinger calls it "detente" with the Russians interested in gaining access to Western technology and know-how. and so far nothing has come out-of it for Ame rica, but plenty for Russia. Does history repeat itseli? OWN BURDEN ' Naturally, Henry Kissin ger. has . inherited a ter rible legacy.. Like Rathenau who wanted to liquidate the defeat of Germany'in the first World War, Henry Kissinger is burdened with the. legacy of Viet nam, with the abolition of the draft, with labor and civil strife at heme, with Watergate, . and most of all, with the decline of the West in moral and poli tical terms with the re sults of a policy that wanted to cure the ills of the world with money, that abandoned the. con cept of power and re nounced the will to resist any encroachrhent on its sources of raw materials and vital interests He is suffering from the results of a policy that encouraged the: indepen dence of countries that were not ready to be in dependent, with a United Nations that always was a Disunited Nations and now has becoifce a menace to the Western world. -In effect, Henry Kissin ger never changed the basic policies this country adopted a, long time ago in spite of .all the window dressing and public rela tions job he does.  He is mainly concerned with improving temporary solutions without attack ing the core of a problem. It is a policy that is . fraught With danger. Its results -are slowly unfold ing. SURROUNDED It is clear that America was confronted with a possible loss of the Medi terranean Sea — in -the south to an Arabian em pire that- stretches from' the Indian .Ocean to. the Atlantic, in the north to possible Communist re gimes in Portugal and Italy, to an independent minded Greece, and to. a tattered Spain and a hos tile Turkey.. Tiny Israel lies in the midst of it all. It is the last stronghold, not of democracy, sis the tired cliche goes, but of power for the West Henry Kissinger could not prevent this Arabian empire from being formed. In the privacy of his office he might assess the reper cussions this new power structure will have, and he ought to realise that this is., a completely new situa tion for the West where the old cliches are fading and: where trust in the rationality of men is dan gerous. Henry Kissinger left: Germany when he was quite young. But he cer tainly was aware of the tactics of a Hitler. He was acquainted with the ruth less lies of totalitarian rulers, their double deal ings, their relentless appe tite, that takes conciliation for weakness, and views bargaining as a stepping stone for new demands. He should have realised the emotional instability and the emotional upsurge that can engulf: an entire people,- an entire region and that can only be treated with-firmness. He thought that he could accommodate. the Arabs by saving them in the face of certain defeat by promising money and wheat and atomic reactors. All he got for it was Rabat arid Arafat. DANGERS His recent speeches con vey a sense of urgency and a tendency towards fiririness. He might have become aware of the im mutable law in dealing with totalitarian regimes — that conciliation and appeasement make a bad situation worse, that every retreat leads to the point of no return, where a stand has to be taken and where no further retreat is possible. Another Munich might loom cn the horizon. But this time it would be the end of Western civilisa tion.  How can Henry Kissin ger survive this? How can wo air survive this? How cm he get out of this bind? If he is successful, he will be a great Ameri can if he fails, he will be the Jew who brought it all about. The rumblings are clear. General George S. Brown with his unguarded remarks should convey it to us all, Henry Kissinger included. The General meant it or he would not have said it. As a refugee from disaster Henry Kis singer should know to be cn guard all the time. Maybe he learned in school the Gefman pro verb: “God, please,. pro tect me from my.friends-1: will take care of my ene mies.” Anwar Sadat called Henry Kissinger his friend. Hopefully, the day will riot come when an elated Arafat is tempted to use the same-word. ' *A lighter moment in Israel (from left) Prime Minister Yitzhak I Rabin, Dr.. Kissinger, Foreign Minister Yigal Alton, the U. S. Am- I bassador, and Defence'Minister Shimon Peres. (Israel Sun).

article_text: WHAT THE NEW PEOPLE BROUGHT COMMUNITY AND IDEN TITY: REFUGEE GROUPS IN ADELAIDE. By Jean I. Martin. ANU Press, 143pp, $5.50. FUTURE AUSTRALIANS: IMMIGRANT CHILDREN IN PERTH, WESTERN AUSTRALIA. By Ruth Johnston. ANU Press, 292pp, $7.95. Reviewer: GEORGE ZUBRZYCKl. JN 1966 the Academy of the Social Sciences in Australia decided to sponsor a project designed to exam ine the contribution of mig rants in Australia's econ omic, social and cultural life. With financial support from government, business and foundation sources some two dozen studies were launched in two major fields: the cultural, political and social (under the direc tion of Dr C. A. Price, pro fessorial fellow in demog raphy at the ANU) and the economic and industrial (under the direction of Pro fessor R. T. Appleyard of the University of Western Australia). The books by Professor Jean Martin of La Trobe Uni versity and Dr Ruth Johnston of the University of Western Australia are the first two re ports on the project, conceived to assist in under standing of Australia's bold adventure and the growing complexity of a nation in which a quarter of the popu lation is of post-war immigrant stock. The two studies under re view and other volumes that will follow in the present ser ies, handsomely produced by aNU Press, are based on one significant assumption which they share with contemporary American writing about immi gration. The recent research in the United States has pro duced a view of the process of immigration from within the American society. This ap . proach begins with the as sumption that the entire pop . ulation of the United States almost from the start, was made up of elements from a multitude of sources. Jn my view, this way of looking at immigration is more meaningful than by con sidering the settlers as a com pletely foreign element. By taking the immigrant as a type of American, this approach contributes to an understand ing of the development of civilisation in the United States and sets immigration in a more comprehensive context. For instance, it has enabled the American social scientists to study the experience of for eign immigrants so that it could supply clues for such problems as the major internal migrations of the 1950s and the 1960s and the urban crisis. The central and most decis ive point of this experience was the breakdown o£ trad itional, communal life. And if we are to follow the historian Oscar Handlin, this critical de velopment has significantly in fluenced American character. Migration led to the de struction of the traditional community of comprehensive and integrated social institu tions, be it in Europe or in other parts whence the settlers had come. The shock of hav ing left behind such a com munity and the adjustment necessary to compensate for its lack in the' New World were the fundamental social experience of the American nation. This, in turn, led to the development in American life which we are gradually be ginning to experience in Aus tralia today. The social scien tists refer to this development as ethnic or cultural plural ism, ie the situation in which group differences form an en during part of social life and provide a source of its enrich ment. What it means in fact is an attempt on the part of the migrants to keep alive dur in g their pilgrimage from peasant commune to industrial metropolis, some of the dif fuse, particularistic modes of behaviour that were common to their past. One is not an ethnic in one's native village, but only when one has left that village for the city or left one's country for the New World. In Ireland we were Mayo men or Cork men in Italy Baresi or Neapolitans or Sicilians in Germany, Swabians or Bavarians or Saxons in Yugoslavia Croats or Slovenes or Serbs in Am erica or Australia we became Irish, Italian, German or Yugoslavs, only when the host society chose to define us as such and we found that the primordial ties of soil and blood could best be described in such terms in the new sett ing in which we found our selves. 'Community and Identity' is a study of the extent and nat ure of cultural pluralism and the process by which plural ism has developed in Adelaide between 1948 and 1967. Pro fessor Martin chose the postwar refugee groups as a subject of her book and studied the chang ing structure and functions of no fewer than 245 associa tions and clubs of various size in an estimated popula tion of 22,000 persons of East European stock. The findings of her carefully documented analysis come as no surprise to students of im migrant groups in other Aus tralian cities. They demon strate, once again, the high degree of cohesion and parti cipation among the Ukrain ians, Estonians and Latvians compared with the internal divisions and lower partici pation rates that characterise the Poles and the Hungarians. More importantly, Professor Martin shows how the ethnic group through its social voca tional and religious associa tions acts as a buffer between the lonely settler and the host society. The group provides him with a meaningful round of activities among people he knows, it supplies him with continuity to his personal past it strengthens his family life and it helps him to un derstand himself and his problems. The Adelaide study also shows how the ethnic group contributes to the welfare of the whole society. It lends diversity to, and thus en riches, our culture so that all of us can profit from the com bined heritages of the various strands of our population. Even more important, by re lieving individual tensions it contributes to the welfare of the whole society. People who enjoy a sound group life are not as likely as others to be come disorganised or to find themselves unable to achieve a psychological identification with Australians. This latter problem of sub jective assimilation is explored in depth by Dr Johnston in her comparison of small sam ples of Australian, British, German and Polish teenagers and their families in Perth. 'Future Australians' reveals the complexity of the process of assimilation in its external and subjective dimensions. Its chief values lies in dispelling the myth of easy assimilation in immigrant children. The fact is that the second generation experiences pain ful problems of psychological adjustment. It is born into an immigrant group but is mar ginal in the sense that it acts both inside and outside the world of its parents. To the extent that its members seek to advance, they often find the old community a handi cap and wish to break away. To the extent that they en counter prejudice and are rebuffed, they may be driven back into it. As Dr Johnson demonstrates, an ethnic group of which many members are in this position is often un stable and torn by conflict. The first two studies in the series 'Immigration in Aus tralia' represent a significant contribution to our knowledge of contemporary Australia. On a larger plane they add to our understanding of (he new pluralism which is developing in Australia as an expression of people who are fighting for humane values: the values of a small community, the values of historical memory, the values of development for the little people in our so ciety. One of the healthy contribu tions that the new pluralism could make would be as an antidote for the ferocity of the machine world, the prac tical world of harsh bureau cracy that seems to have be come one of the major attri butes of industrialised societies today.
